title: Taper Talk at the ECB; Atlanta Fed 's Bostic Concerned About Evictions
text:
Top News

European Bond Yields Rise on ECB Tapering Bets

Investors are betting that with the eurozone's economic prospects brightening, the European Central Bank will pare back its purchase of government bonds through a program that was meant to bolster credit markets and growth during the pandemic.

"We could see taper talk coming from the ECB," said James Athey, an investment manager at Aberdeen Standard Investments. Extending the pandemic emergency purchase program "is hard to justify when growth is strong, inflation is high and unemployment is falling," he added.

Fed's Bostic Warns Eviction Surge Could Weigh on Recovery

Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said Wednesday that ending protections against evictions and a slow rollout of aid for renters owing money to landlords could create problems for the economic recovery.

Related: New York Poised to Join Ranks of States Extending Eviction Moratorium

U.S. Economy

Unemployment Claims Trending at Pandemic Lows

New applications for unemployment benefits are likely to hold near pandemic lows, showing the labor market is progressing despite uncertainty caused by the Delta variant of Covid-19.

States That Cut Jobless Benefits Saw Limited Impact on Job Growth

States that ended enhanced federal unemployment benefits early have so far seen about the same job growth as states that continued offering the extra aid, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis and economists.

White House to Unveil Steps to Ease Housing Supply Shortage

Changes would draw upon the administrative authority of regulators such as the Federal Housing Finance Agency as Congress weighs policy changes tied to the debate over revamping U.S. infrastructure, according to a draft plan.

Key Developments Around the World

OPEC Alliance Keeps Gradual Output Increases, Despite U.S. Request

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and a group of Russia-led producers said they will continue increasing oil production in measured steps, resisting for now recent U.S. pressure to open the group's spigots wider.

Surging Covid-19 Cases Hammer Asian Factories

Factory activity faltered across Asia in August, with a resurgence in Covid-19 infections adding to global supply-chain disruptions and confirming fears of a slowdown in the region's economic recovery.

For Afghans Abroad, Sending Money Home Is Harder Than Ever

Many Afghans get by with financial help from family members living abroad. But those remittances have become much harder to send and receive in the weeks since the Taliban gained control of the country.

Financial Regulation Roundup

SEC Considers Asking Funds for Criteria Used to Tout Sustainability

Asset managers saying they allocate capital to environmentally or socially responsible companies might have to back up those claims as Wall Street's main regulator considers whether to require them to disclose their criteria.

SEC Sues BitConnect and Founder, Alleging Massive Cryptocurrency Scam of World-Wide Investors

The Securities and Exchange Commission accused offshore company BitConnect and its founder, Satish Kumbhani, of a $2 billion fraud that misused bitcoin raised from investors world-wide.

Forward Guidance

Thursday (all times ET)

8:30 a.m.: U.S. Commerce Department releases July international trade data

Friday

8:30 a.m.: U.S. Labor Department releases August jobs report

Research

NY Fed Weighs In With Report on September 2019 Market Tumult

A new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York seeks to untangle the unexpected surge in short-term interest rates in September 2019 that drove the Federal Reserve into regular short-term interventions aimed at keeping its interest rate target in line. The report says a shortage of bank reserves was indeed an issue then. The report also points to another reason for the upward pressure in short-term rates: "Intermediation costs for some large domestic dealers likely rose due to a temporary reduction in lending from money market mutual funds, including through the Fixed Income Clearing Corporation 's sponsored repo program, leading dealers to charge higher spreads to ultimate cash borrowers."

Commentary

How to Deal With Above-Target Inflation: Raise the Target

Many economists argue that raising the Federal Reserve's inflation target from 2% will result in fewer, and less severe, recessions, Greg Ip writes.

American Factories Will Keep Humming

Even if Covid-19's resurgence cuts into Americans' penchant for spending, factories will probably keep on humming, assuming of course, that they can get the parts and labor, Justin Lahart writes.

Basis Points

U.S. manufacturing kept expanding at a solid pace in August but persistent supply-chain challenges constrained growth, according to a survey of purchasing managers in the sector. The ISM Manufacturing Report on Business PMI rose to 59.9 in August from 59.5 in July, according to data from the Institute for Supply Management released Wednesday. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the index to come in at 58.6. (Dow Jones Newswires)

China's State Council said it will increase the central bank's relending quota by 300 billion yuan ($46.4 billion) this year to support struggling small businesses and keep economic growth within a reasonable range.

The Bank of England named the former chief European economist at Goldman Sachs, Huw Pill, as its chief economist. He replaces Andy Haldane , who left over the summer, and as chief economist Mr. Pill will vote on the interest-rate setting Monetary Policy Committee. He most recently was a senior lecturer at Harvard Business School and has held senior roles at the European Central Bank . (DJN)

The jobless rate in the eurozone continued to decline in July, as the reopening after the easing of pandemic-related restrictions fueled a strong economic recovery over summer. The rate fell from a revised 7.8% in June to 7.6%, Eurostat data showed. The reading matches forecasts from economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. (DJN)

Eurozone manufacturing activity held up in August and seems to have grown at a solid pace, albeit losing some momentum amid supplier shortages and inflation pressures, as the final reading for the eurozone's manufacturing PMI for the month came in at 61.4, a six-month low, data from IHS Markit showed. This was down from 62.8 in July and marginally below the 61.5 preliminary estimate. A reading above 50 indicates expansion, while below this threshold signals a contraction. (DJN)

Italy's unemployment rate continued to decline in July, edging down from a downwardly revised 9.4% in June to 9.3%, the lowest level since May 2020, as the country's economic recovery gathered momentum in the summer, data from statistics office Istat showed. (DJN)

U.S. nonfarm private employment increased by 374,000 in August, data from ADP National Employment Report showed Wednesday, missing the 600,000 rise expected by economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. (DJN)

U.S. construction spending rose 0.3% on month in July after stagnating the previous month, according to the Commerce Department. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected a 0.2% rise. (DJN)

Brazil's economy contracted slightly in the second quarter from the previous three months as industrial activity shrank due to supply problems and agriculture was hit by a decline in the coffee harvest. Gross domestic product shrank a seasonally adjusted 0.1% from the first quarter and rose 12.4% from a year earlier, the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics said. In the first quarter, GDP grew by 1.2% from the previous three months and 1.0% from a year earlier. (DJN)

Brazil's trade surplus widened from $7.4 billion in July to $7.7 billion in August as exports increased more than imports, according to the economy ministry. (DJN)

Remittances to Mexico rose to a record $4.54 billion in July, up 29% from a year earlier and 3.9% higher than in June in seasonally adjusted terms, the Bank of Mexico said. July marked a fifth consecutive month above $4 billion and brought the total for the January-July period to $28.19 billion, a 24% increase from the first seven months of 2020. (DJN)
